This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2024-07-16 11:00:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/26114). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

Following the 2024 EU Parliament elections, France saw the rise of the right wing National Rally. This made French president Emmanuel Macron call early legislative elections and dissolution of the National Assembly, in response. 

Following the 2024 french legislative elections, the National Assembly has been mostly split three-ways, between the big tent, left wing grouping [New Popular Front with 180 seats; the centrist Ensemble with 159 seats; and the aforementioned National rally with 142 seats. None of the above gaining a majority in the 577 seat parliament](https://www.resultats-elections.interieur.gouv.fr/legislatives2024/ensemble_geographique/index.html). Some feel that this polarized parliament could lead to government deadlock, with any formed government potentially having a hard time surviving a motion of no confidence against it. This may potentially lead to Macron calling another snap election before the next scheduled legislative election, to ease the potential deadlock, which the french constitution only allow after a year since the previous legislative election.

See also from Le Monde: [Snap elections in France: How it works, precedents, and consequences](https://www.lemonde.fr/en/les-decodeurs/article/2024/06/10/snap-elections-in-france-how-it-works-precedents-and-consequences_6674391_8.html)

Macron then appointed François Bayrou, leader of the Democratic Movement (Modem), as PM.  Bayrou’s appointment was seen as a continuation of Macron’s politics, and the article describes his attempt to "overcome the Himalaya" of political divisions.  Bayrou survived a no‑confidence motion in January 2025 thanks to the Socialist Party (PS), but was again ousted in September 2025 over a budget dispute that included the removal of two public holidays and a proposed 44 billion‑euro savings plan, while the left demanded only 22 billion euros.

The article concludes that the appointment of Sébastien Lecornu as Bayrou’s successor offers no clear prospects.  Lecornu, a long‑time minister, may face the same fate as his predecessors, potentially leading to another dissolution of the Assembly and a possible co‑habitation, the first since 1997.  The piece uses a negative tone, describing the events as "political mistakes" and "suicide politique", and emphasizes the instability and lack of clear direction.

**Budget: The First Unfinished Draft of Sébastien Lecornu**
Sébastien Lecornu’s first budget proposals for 2026, unveiled in a lengthy interview with Le Parisien, were met with a cold reception from both the left‑wing parties and the National Rally. The proposals included a veto on the Zucman tax, the return of the ISF, a suspension – and even a possible abolition – of the pension reform, a tentative opening to the right on state medical aid, and vague statements on other matters such as public spending cuts and a “blank year”.  The Parisian press described the PM’s remarks as a “main vide” and “mots creux”.  For the Socialist Party (PS), the promised break was absent; Olivier Faure warned that the party would meet the PM next week and, if no major change occurs, will move to censure the government.  The PS feels empowered by the broad public support for its fiscal and pension proposals, while the PM’s confidence rating is at a historic low and his coalition – comprising Renaissance, Modem, UDI, Horizons and Les Républicains – remains fragile.  A new mobilisation day is scheduled for 2 October, with the PM expected to convene a meeting with the socialists that Friday and a fourth meeting with the coalition on Monday.  The PM’s strategy is to avoid after‑sales support, limiting himself to two written interviews and no radio or TV appearances, which has led to accusations of “dure” tactics.  The National Rally accuses the PM of “trying to buy time”, and the RN’s Jean‑Philippe Tanguy calls for a swift dissolution.  The PM promised a government “before the parliamentary work begins”, implying a deadline of 1 October or, more realistically, by the end of the week.  The article quotes the PM’s own words: ‘Nous rencontrerons une dernière fois le Premier ministre la semaine prochaine à sa demande. Nous prendrons ensuite notre décision : sans changement majeur d’orientation, nous censurerons ce gouvernement’.  It also cites a Macron‑supporter: ‘Il fera des concessions au PS pendant le débat, ce qui permettra à Olivier Faure d’afficher des victoires dans les prochaines semaines’.  The piece concludes that the next week will be decisive, with the first no‑confidence motion expected from La France Insoumise.

**Sarkozy Conviction Sparks Debate Over Political Justice in France Ahead of Le Pen’s Candidacy**
The Paris court’s conviction of former President Nicolas Sarkozy on 18 April 2024 for criminal conspiracy related to an attempt to obtain campaign funds from Libya has intensified France’s debate over the politicisation of its judiciary.  The judge handed Sarkozy a five‑year prison term, making him the first post‑World‑War II French president to be incarcerated.  According to the court, the sentence is immediately enforceable, but the president is allowed a short period to settle his affairs; he is not permitted to avoid imprisonment pending appeal.  "The verdict shows that no one is above the law," said Ludovic Friat, president of the USM, the largest union of French prosecutors and judges.  "There will be a clear before‑and‑after to this decision," he added.  The article reports that 89 % of sentences longer than two years are enforced before an appeal is concluded, a figure cited by Judith Allenbach, president of another judges’ association.  The conviction has prompted calls for the abolition of the practice of immediately enforceable sentences.  Meanwhile, Marine Le Pen, the leader of the far‑right National Rally, faces a separate five‑year political ban for alleged EU‑fund embezzlement, which could bar her from running in the 2027 election.  Le Pen’s supporters claim that right‑wing politicians are treated more harshly by judges, citing the acquittal of former centrist Prime Minister François Bayrou.  The article also notes that US President Donald Trump has described Le Pen as a victim of "lawfare" and has sent a diplomatic delegation in her support.  French political figures are divided: conservative Senate president Gérard Larcher expressed concern over the debate on immediate enforcement, while left‑wing MP Manuel Bompard praised the call for honesty and rule of law.  Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu said that any legal debate should be addressed by Parliament.
